title: Chinese Government cancels RMB 249,730,000 of the Government of DRC’s outstanding debt obligations
description: In 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo signed a debt exemption protocol, which cancelled RMB 249,730,000 of the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s outstanding debt obligations.
staff_comments: China made a concerted effort in 2007 to forgive the debt from interest-free loans maturing by the end of 2005 to heavily-indebted African countries (http://kp.china-embassy.org/chn//zgxw/zgzxxw/t293317.htm). Since interest-free loans usually have 20 year maturities (http://www.gov.cn/zwgk/2011-04/21/content_1850553.htm), we have assumed the loans included in this debt forgiveness package would have been contracted before 2000. As such, this project is not marked as umbrella, as there is little risk of double counting.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government cancels RMB 249,730,000 of the Government of DRC’s outstanding debt obligations

# Description
In 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo signed a debt exemption protocol, which cancelled RMB 249,730,000 of the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s outstanding debt obligations.
justification: Debt cancellation is a financial transaction without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt exemption protocol, financial obligation cancellation

title: Chinese Government provides additional $8.5 million for Phases 2 and 3 of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Technical Cooperation Project in N'sele (Linked to Project ID#58964 and #58965)
description: On August 4, 2006, the Chinese ambassador to DRC, Fan Zhenshui, went to N'sele to attend the inauguration ceremony of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Centre (also referred to as Upland Crops) (French project name: Projet de Vulgarisation Des Cultures Pluviales à Kinshasa/N'sele). The construction of basic infrastructure at the demonstration center was completed in November 2007. Then, in 2008, the project transitioned to a technical cooperation arrangement.   The first phase of the technical cooperation was carried out from August 2009 to August 2010 by Shandong International Economic and Technological Cooperation Company. The Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) records a 2007 commitment value of $8,535,963.37 from the Chinese Embassy for supplemental funding to support Phases II and III of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project [French project name: La coopération sous le projet de vulgarisation des cultures pluviales à Kinshasa/ à N'sele (2è et 3ème phase)]. The final amount disbursed was $8,535,437.98. Separate financial commitments for Phases II and III are captured in the linked projects #58964 and #58965.  There are five known technical cooperation phases for the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project: Phase I: $3,420,254 (recorded in project #58963)  Phase II: $1,485,974 (recorded in project #58964)  Phase III: $673,453 (recorded in project #58965)  Phase IV: $353,039 (recorded in project #58966)  Phase V: $1,140,985 (recorded in project #58967)  The additional financing for the 2nd and 3rd technical cooperation phase is recorded in this project, and a project to bring water and electricity and level the land of the site worth $364,701 is recorded in project #58969.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides additional $8.5 million for Phases 2 and 3 of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Technical Cooperation Project in N'sele (Linked to Project ID#58964 and #58965)

# Description
On August 4, 2006, the Chinese ambassador to DRC, Fan Zhenshui, went to N'sele to attend the inauguration ceremony of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Centre (also referred to as Upland Crops) (French project name: Projet de Vulgarisation Des Cultures Pluviales à Kinshasa/N'sele). The construction of basic infrastructure at the demonstration center was completed in November 2007. Then, in 2008, the project transitioned to a technical cooperation arrangement.   The first phase of the technical cooperation was carried out from August 2009 to August 2010 by Shandong International Economic and Technological Cooperation Company. The Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) records a 2007 commitment value of $8,535,963.37 from the Chinese Embassy for supplemental funding to support Phases II and III of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project [French project name: La coopération sous le projet de vulgarisation des cultures pluviales à Kinshasa/ à N'sele (2è et 3ème phase)]. The final amount disbursed was $8,535,437.98. Separate financial commitments for Phases II and III are captured in the linked projects #58964 and #58965.  There are five known technical cooperation phases for the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project: Phase I: $3,420,254 (recorded in project #58963)  Phase II: $1,485,974 (recorded in project #58964)  Phase III: $673,453 (recorded in project #58965)  Phase IV: $353,039 (recorded in project #58966)  Phase V: $1,140,985 (recorded in project #58967)  The additional financing for the 2nd and 3rd technical cooperation phase is recorded in this project, and a project to bring water and electricity and level the land of the site worth $364,701 is recorded in project #58969.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural development and technical cooperation without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Rain-fed crop demonstration center, technical cooperation phases, agricultural development focus

title: Chinese Government provides $7.7 million grant for construction of housing for Chinese medical mission and technical cooperation experts at the Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital (Linked to project #438)
description: In 2007, the Chinese Government provided a $7,692,307.69 grant to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo for the construction of housing for the Chinese medical mission and technical cooperation experts at the Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital in N'djili. According to the Aid Management Platform (AMP) of the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo, this project commenced on March 1, 2009. The AMP also indicates that the grant was fully disbursed as of December 31, 2007. The French project title is Construction des logements pour la mission médicale chinoise et les experts de la coopération technique à l'hôpital de N'djili.
combined_text:

The AMP also indicates that the grant was fully disbursed as of December 31, 2007. The French project title is Construction des logements pour la mission médicale chinoise et les experts de la coopération technique à l'hôpital de N'djili.

title: Chinese Government makes 2nd annual anti-malarial drug donation (Linked to Project ID#59101)
description: In 2007, the Chinese government granted the second annual batch of malaria medication to Democratic Republic of Congo. As part of a FOCAC commitment, the Chinese government donated malaria medication every year from 2006-2016 (see project #59101).  The yearly donations are as follows:  2006: #19719  2007: #59102  2008: #59104  2009: #59105  2010: #59106  2011: #59108  2012: #59109  2013: #59111  2014: #53518  2015: #52957  2016: #58975

title: Chinese Government donates 10 computers to DRC’s Ministry of Higher Education
description: On December 13, 2007, the Chinese government granted 10 computers to the Democratic Republic of Congo Ministry of Higher Education. The value of the donation is unknown. The donation was reportedly a response of the Chinese government to the request of DRC's Ministry of Higher Education in August 2006. This project is completed.

title: China Development Bank lends $105 million to Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) to pay for ZTE's services in 2007 (Linked to Project ID#382 and #95662)
description: On December 14, 2000, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a RMB 80 million ($9,664,765.67) concessional loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The proceeds of loan, which is captured via Project ID#382, were used to support the creation of joint venture between ZTE and the Congolese Office of Post Telecommunications (OCPT) in Kinshasa, called Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) or Congo-China Telecom S.A.R.L. (CCT) (Chinese name: 刚中电讯有限公司). ZTE held a 51% equity stake in the joint venture, and OCPT held a 49% equity stake. Most of the loan proceeds were used to be used by the borrower to acquire equipment from ZTE and thereby build CCT’s telecommunications network in the DRC.   According to the Aid Management Platform (AMP) of the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo, the loan achieved a 100% disbursement rate ($9,665,149.43 out of $9,664,765.67). CCT launched GSM-900/1800 services on December 31, 2001 in Katanga in the east of the country. It subsequently rolled out services to Kinshasa, Bas-Congo, Bandundu and the two provinces of Kasai, giving it coverage in 40 cities. The CCT network, at the time, had a capacity for 150,000 customers, with a single switch in Kinshasa, and it used a Belgacom earth station for its international gateway. Then, on March 11, 2006, ZTE Corporation signed a sales contract and a service contract with Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) worth $123 million.   On June 29, 2007, the China Development Bank (as arranger, initial lender and facility agent) signed the Phase I and Phase II loan facility agreements with CCT (as borrower). The aggregate loan amount was $105 million (covering Phase I with $63 million and Phase II with $42 million). The proceeds of the loan, which is captured via Project ID#60113, were to be used to finance CCT’s payments to ZTE Corporation worth 85% of the cost of the 2006 sales and service contract. The 2007 loan was guaranteed by the ZTE Corporation's 51% equity interest (see Project ID#383) in Congo-Chine Télécom (CCT). The Ministry of State-owned Enterprises of Congo (Kinshasa) provided a counter-guarantee by pledging its 25% equity interest in CCT. The loan was also secured with (i.e. collateralized against) fixed assets purchased by the borrower with the loan proceeds.   Then, on October 20, 2011, France Telecom-Orange (FT-Orange) acquired a 100% ownership stake in CCT  (the majority of which was assumed debt), buying the 51% ownership stake held by the ZTE Corporation and the 49% ownership stake held the Congolese State. Under the terms of a share purchase agreement signed with ZTE Corporation, FT-Orange agreed to pay $10 million (EUR 7 million) to the Chinese equipment manufacturer for its 51% stake in CCT. Under the terms of a share purchase agreement signed with the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (after a call for tenders), FT-Orange agreed to pay $7 million (EUR 5 million) to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo for its 49% stake in CCT.  CCT was renamed ‘Orange RDC’ and the Orange brand was introduced to the DRC on December 6, 2012. As part of the October 2011 acquisition, Orange RDC (formerly Congo Chine Télécoms or CCT) signed a $276,250,000 loan agreement with China Development Bank (captured via Project ID#95662). The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to repay the outstanding (assumed) debts of CCT and to expand CCT’s existing telecommunications network.   In the last quarter of 2011, FT-Orange also announced that ZTE Corporation would provide it with infrastructure and services as a preferred supplier, drawing upon ‘strategic financing support’ from China Development Bank. Following the October 2011 acquisition, FT-Orange invested CDF 87.4 billion ($89.6 million) to expand and enhance CCT’s telecommunications network, including an upgrade to 3G. Orange RDC had 1.8 million mobile customers as of December 2012. By the end of 2014, Orange RDC had 14.3 million mobile customers.
staff_comments: 1. Neither CDB loan is included in the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020. Nor is either loan included in the China’s Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University's Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.2. On November 8, 2007, ZTE entered into a supplier’s share pledge agreement with the agent bank of China Development Bank in DRC, pursuant to which ZTE provided pledge of share in respect of the said $105 million bank loan extended to CCT on the back of its 51% equity interests in CCT. The guarantee was considered and approved at the Seventh Meeting of the Fourth Session of the Board of Directors and the Third Extraordinary Meeting for 2007 convened by ZTE on August 16, 2007 and October 16, 2007, respectively. Pursuant to a Sale and Purchase Agreement, France Telecom-Orange agreed to provide capital contributions to CCT on the completion date for the Sale Shares, and the funds were to be applied towards prepayment of all loan balances under the two $63 million and $42 million facility agreements with China Development Bank. China Development Bank agreed to sign a series of documents with the parties on the same date of the loan repayment, terminating the $63 million and $42 million facility agreements and the share pledge agreement, releasing CCT and ZTE from all obligations under the facility agreement and the share pledge agreement as well as releasing Share from the aforesaid pledge.3. At the end of 2008, CCT was the smallest of DRC’s four wireless network operators, with just over 115,00 customers or 1% of the total subscriber base. It was competing, at the time, with Vodacom (with 47% market share at the same date), Zain (38%) and Millicom International Cellular’s Oasis (Tigo, 12%).4. Some sources indicated that on October 21, 2011 ZTE sold its 51% equity stake in CCT to Pan Communication Investments and Atlas International Investments (both of which are wholly-owned subsidiaries of France Telecom) and that the transfer of equity ownership was completed on the same date.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Development Bank lends $105 million to Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) to pay for ZTE's services in 2007 (Linked to Project ID#382 and #95662)

# Description
On December 14, 2000, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a RMB 80 million ($9,664,765.67) concessional loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The proceeds of loan, which is captured via Project ID#382, were used to support the creation of joint venture between ZTE and the Congolese Office of Post Telecommunications (OCPT) in Kinshasa, called Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) or Congo-China Telecom S.A.R.L. (CCT) (Chinese name: 刚中电讯有限公司). ZTE held a 51% equity stake in the joint venture, and OCPT held a 49% equity stake. Most of the loan proceeds were used to be used by the borrower to acquire equipment from ZTE and thereby build CCT’s telecommunications network in the DRC.   According to the Aid Management Platform (AMP) of the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo, the loan achieved a 100% disbursement rate ($9,665,149.43 out of $9,664,765.67). CCT launched GSM-900/1800 services on December 31, 2001 in Katanga in the east of the country. It subsequently rolled out services to Kinshasa, Bas-Congo, Bandundu and the two provinces of Kasai, giving it coverage in 40 cities. The CCT network, at the time, had a capacity for 150,000 customers, with a single switch in Kinshasa, and it used a Belgacom earth station for its international gateway. Then, on March 11, 2006, ZTE Corporation signed a sales contract and a service contract with Congo-Chine Télécoms (CCT) worth $123 million.   On June 29, 2007, the China Development Bank (as arranger, initial lender and facility agent) signed the Phase I and Phase II loan facility agreements with CCT (as borrower). The aggregate loan amount was $105 million (covering Phase I with $63 million and Phase II with $42 million). The proceeds of the loan, which is captured via Project ID#60113, were to be used to finance CCT’s payments to ZTE Corporation worth 85% of the cost of the 2006 sales and service contract. The 2007 loan was guaranteed by the ZTE Corporation's 51% equity interest (see Project ID#383) in Congo-Chine Télécom (CCT). The Ministry of State-owned Enterprises of Congo (Kinshasa) provided a counter-guarantee by pledging its 25% equity interest in CCT. The loan was also secured with (i.e. collateralized against) fixed assets purchased by the borrower with the loan proceeds.   Then, on October 20, 2011, France Telecom-Orange (FT-Orange) acquired a 100% ownership stake in CCT  (the majority of which was assumed debt), buying the 51% ownership stake held by the ZTE Corporation and the 49% ownership stake held the Congolese State. Under the terms of a share purchase agreement signed with ZTE Corporation, FT-Orange agreed to pay $10 million (EUR 7 million) to the Chinese equipment manufacturer for its 51% stake in CCT. Under the terms of a share purchase agreement signed with the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (after a call for tenders), FT-Orange agreed to pay $7 million (EUR 5 million) to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo for its 49% stake in CCT.  CCT was renamed ‘Orange RDC’ and the Orange brand was introduced to the DRC on December 6, 2012. As part of the October 2011 acquisition, Orange RDC (formerly Congo Chine Télécoms or CCT) signed a $276,250,000 loan agreement with China Development Bank (captured via Project ID#95662). The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to repay the outstanding (assumed) debts of CCT and to expand CCT’s existing telecommunications network.   In the last quarter of 2011, FT-Orange also announced that ZTE Corporation would provide it with infrastructure and services as a preferred supplier, drawing upon ‘strategic financing support’ from China Development Bank. Following the October 2011 acquisition, FT-Orange invested CDF 87.4 billion ($89.6 million) to expand and enhance CCT’s telecommunications network, including an upgrade to 3G. Orange RDC had 1.8 million mobile customers as of December 2012. By the end of 2014, Orange RDC had 14.3 million mobile customers.
justification: Project focuses on telecommunications infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Telecommunications network development, GSM services, network expansion, and 3G upgrade

title: China donates anti-malarial drugs worth 12 million DJF to Djibouti
description: On 5 December 2007, the Chinese Ambassador Wang Xiaodu officially handed over anti-malaria medicine worth 12 million DJF (approximately 500,000 RMB) to the Djibouti Ministry of Health. The ceremony took place at the Central Purchasing Center for Essential Materials and Medicines headquarters in Djibouti.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates anti-malarial drugs worth 12 million DJF to Djibouti

# Description
On 5 December 2007, the Chinese Ambassador Wang Xiaodu officially handed over anti-malaria medicine worth 12 million DJF (approximately 500,000 RMB) to the Djibouti Ministry of Health. The ceremony took place at the Central Purchasing Center for Essential Materials and Medicines headquarters in Djibouti.
justification: Project is a healthcare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of anti-malarial drugs, healthcare sector focus

title: China grants DJF 40 million for construction of kidney dialysis ward at General Peltier Hospital (Linked to #59170, #72358)
description: On 29 March, 2007, China Jiangxi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation and the Djibouti Ministry of Health signed a supplementary contract for the construction of a kidney dialysis ward at General Peltier hospital (other project names: Une salle de dialyse à l'Hôpital Général Peltier or Création d’une unité de dialyse à Djibouti or 吉布提肾透析病房项目). According to a report from the World Health Organization (source ID 112332 p. 39), China granted DJF 40 million for this project.   China Jiangxi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project was completed and handed over to the authorities on 17 January 2008.  China previously donated dialysis equipment to Djibouti in 2003 (#59170) and trained Djibouti healthcare workers for this new dialysis center in 2008 (#72358).
staff_comments: The Chinese Government provided RMB 200,000 in grant funding (See: 'NOTE SUR LE FINANCEMENT EXTERIEUR Programme d’Investissements Publics par bailleurs') to support the supplementary contract that was signed on 29 March, 2007. However, it is unclear if this amount is part of or separate from the 40 million Djiboutian francs of grant funding that was committed for the creation of the kidney dialysis ward. Therefore, we exclude it from our estimate of the face value of the grant commitment.Since the commitment year is uncertain, it is coded as 2007 for now in correspondence with when the two sides signed the supplementary implementation contract.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China grants DJF 40 million for construction of kidney dialysis ward at General Peltier Hospital (Linked to #59170, #72358)

# Description
On 29 March, 2007, China Jiangxi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation and the Djibouti Ministry of Health signed a supplementary contract for the construction of a kidney dialysis ward at General Peltier hospital (other project names: Une salle de dialyse à l'Hôpital Général Peltier or Création d’une unité de dialyse à Djibouti or 吉布提肾透析病房项目). According to a report from the World Health Organization (source ID 112332 p. 39), China granted DJF 40 million for this project.   China Jiangxi International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project was completed and handed over to the authorities on 17 January 2008.  China previously donated dialysis equipment to Djibouti in 2003 (#59170) and trained Djibouti healthcare workers for this new dialysis center in 2008 (#72358).
justification: Project focuses on healthcare infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Construction of kidney dialysis ward at hospital, healthcare focus

title: China funds and builds an administrative annex building at the Djiboutian Presidential Palace
description: In 2007, the Chinese government granted 12 million DJF to the Government of Djibouti for the construction of an administrative annex building at the Djiboutian Presidential Palace (in French: un bâtiment annexe administratif de la Présidence).   On 13 November 2007, a Chinese embassy official and Djibouti Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation signed a supplementary design contract for this small office building of the Presidential Palace of Djibouti. The project was designed by China Building Technique Group Co., Ltd. and constructed by Xinjiang International Economic Cooperation Corporation. Construction began on 5 April 2007 and then and handed over to Djibouti authorities on 27 February 2008.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China funds and builds an administrative annex building at the Djiboutian Presidential Palace

# Description
In 2007, the Chinese government granted 12 million DJF to the Government of Djibouti for the construction of an administrative annex building at the Djiboutian Presidential Palace (in French: un bâtiment annexe administratif de la Présidence).   On 13 November 2007, a Chinese embassy official and Djibouti Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation signed a supplementary design contract for this small office building of the Presidential Palace of Djibouti. The project was designed by China Building Technique Group Co., Ltd. and constructed by Xinjiang International Economic Cooperation Corporation. Construction began on 5 April 2007 and then and handed over to Djibouti authorities on 27 February 2008.
justification: Project involves construction of administrative office building with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Administrative annex building at Presidential Palace, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China donates 360 computers to the University of Djibouti
description: On 2 and 3 September 2007, Chinese and Djibouti government officials signed letters of exchange for a project to provide 360 computers to the University of Djibouti. The value of this donation is unknown.   The computers were delivered to the University of Djibouti on 20 January 2008. These computers were to be installed in the university’s 12 information technology rooms.
staff_comments: French project title is “un don de 360 ordinateurs” (See: Remise du Don de 360 ordinateurs du Gouvernement chinois à Djibouti).
combined_text:
